data.title: Kill Bill Vol. 2 and this week's other new movie releases
data.meta_description: The box office has been anything but surprising the last several weeks. After Easter Sunday, The Passion of the Christ  reclaimed the top box office position, with the top seven movies all showing a â€¦
data.text:
The box office has been anything but surprising the last several weeks. After Easter Sunday, The Passion of the Christ

reclaimed the top box office position, with the top seven movies all showing a strong presence.

This week is strange because two vendetta movies are being

released this week: Kill Bill Vol. 2 and The Punisher. The streak of vengeance-focused plotlines culminates next week

with Man on Fire.

Kill Bill Vol. 2

The Premise: Continuing where Vol. 1 left off, The Bride

(played by the lovely Uma Thurman, sans the yellow biker suit

from the original) continues her quest to kill off the remaining parties who killed her family. David Carradine (as Bill) and Daryl Hannah (Elle Driver) have more pronounced roles in this version, and the critical acclaim is nearly Return of the King high (91% positive, according to rottentomatoes.com).

The Buzz: When the theatrical release of Vol. 2 was postponed for two months, I admit I was a little scared that audiences

would lose touch with the plot line, but with the intense amount of

promotion, the additional two months seemed to do nothing but

build anticipation for the film.

Bottom Line: If you haven't seen Vol. 1, grab it on

DVD -- it just came out Tuesday. This edition is guaranteed to be

more fun and campier than the first volume (and that includes the soundtrack), and you'll regret not catching this bad boy in the theater if you don't hustle on down to see it. But leave your samurai sword at home. You don't need any more indictments on your record after the

cow-pushing debacle.

The Punisher

The Premise: Based on the Marvel comic, Thomas

Jane stars as Frank Castle, a special agent who loses his

family at the hands of a criminal. After the justice system

fails to punish (or even find) the assailant, Castle

takes matters into his own hands. He has a personal vendetta,

and will execute his vengeance with his own particular flair.

The Buzz: Rookie director Jonathan Hensliegh, who

wrote the screenplay, also wrote the screenplay for mega-hit

Armageddon.

Bottom Line: The bottomline premise echoes of A Man Apart and next week's Man on Fire, among others. However, with movie adaptations of comic books becoming better (think X-Men 2 and Hellboy - not Daredevil), it's possible Punisher might not be a punitive experience, but rather an enjoyable one.

John Travolta, Rebecca Romijn-Stamos and Roy Scheider co-star.

Connie and Carla

The Premise: In order to hide from the Mafia after seeing something not meant for them to see, friends Connie and Carla (Nia Vardalos and Toni Collette, respectively) hide out in the least obvious place (in their minds) -- Las Vegas. In order to thwart detection, they take jobs as drag queens, even though they are straight females. Subsequently, finding Mr. Right becomes much more difficult. Hilarity ensues.

The Buzz: Two highly adored indie-gold actresses from two of the most acclaimed indie-crossover hits (My Big Fat Greek Wedding and Muriel's Wedding) and David Duchovny's return to feature films. What's not to love?

Bottom Line: I'm going out on a limb here: C & C has the makings of one of the funniest films of the year.

Trailers

Kill Bill Vol. 2: http://www.apple.com/trailers/miramax/kill_bill/volume_II/trailer/

Connie and Carla: http://www.apple.com/trailers/universal/connie_and_carla/

The Punisher: http://www.apple.com/trailers/lions_gate/the_punisher/trailer2/
